Stephen Vreeland v. Joseph Loubat and Francis Cottenett. The mortgagor having disposed of the equity of redemption, and having no interest in the mortgaged premises, is not a necessary party to a bill for foreclosure. The bill in this cause was filed for foreclosure of the equity of redemption, and sale of the mortgaged premises. The defendants were the purchasers of the equity of redemption, the mortgagor having disposed of his interest in the premises to them. The mortgagor was not a party. The defendants demurred for want of parties. The canse came on for hearing upon the demurrer. I. H. Williamson, for complainant. J. D. Miller, for the defendants.

For the complainant it was contended, that the mortgagor, having parted with his intertst in the premises, was not a necessary or proper party to the hill. The proceeding is in rem. He cannot with safety he made a party. If it appear upon the face of the bill that the mortgagor has no interest, he may demur; if otherwise, he may answer, showing that he has no interest, and subject the complainant to costs.

*105The Chancellor.

It lias been usual to make the mortgagor, who has parted with the equity of redemption, a defendant to a bill for foreclosure, hut he is not a necessary party. The proceeding is in rem. An account may be taken without him. There is no reason why he should he made a party.

The demurrer must' be overruled, with costs.

Cited in Bruen v. Crane, 1 Gr. ch. 348; Whittemore v. Coster, 3 Gr. ch. 438; Savings Ass. v. Vandervere, 3 Stock. 383; Harrison’s Ad. v. Johnson, 3 C. E. Gr. 425.
